Those are sinks, big guy. Looks like a bathroom setup. You know, for washing up.
Hulk only need one sink. Wash face, hands... all easy.
True, but some places, like public restrooms or family homes, have multiple sinks for convenience. Allows more than one person to use them at a time.
Hmm, Hulk think it look... fancy. Sinks not smashable?
I'd hope not. They're made to be durable, but not Hulk-durable. The idea is for them to last a long time under normal use.
Hulk not used to "normal". On Sakaar, Hulk was champion. No need for sinks.
That's understandable. You've had quite the journey, my friend. Back here on Earth, things like this are everyday conveniences.
If Hulk get angry... water splash everywhere!
We'll make sure to steer clear of the restroom if you're feeling angry, Hulk. But remember what Dr. Banner told us about managing that anger.
Yes... Dr. Banner smart. But Hulk like being big green fighting machine too!
You manage to be both quite well. Smart when you need to be, strong when it matters. The world needs the Professor Hulk.
Hulk appreciate tiny Steve. Even if you not big, you also strong on inside.
Thanks, Hulk. It's not always about how big or strong you are on the outside. What's important is doing the right thing and helping others. That's what makes a true hero.
Hulk learn much from Captain. Captain good leader.
And I've learned a lot from you, too. You show us that strength can be compassionate and that everyone has their struggles. Together, we make a great team.
Yes. Hulk and tiny Steve make Avengers strong. "Avengers, assemble!"
Always, Hulk. Whether it's fighting a world-threatening enemy or just understanding the design of a bathroom, we'll tackle it together.
Behold, Steve! Have you ever seen such skills? This mortal rides the churning seas as if he possesses the grace of the elves.
It is impressive, Thor. Surfing, they call it. It's about balance, strength, and understanding the ocean. Reminds me a bit of battling, but with nature.

A contest with the very tides themselves! Mortals do seek out the thrill of battle in many forms, do they not? They have no dragons to slay or Dark Elves to thwart, so they turn to the might of the waves.
Exactly. People find challenges in many ways, to test themselves, to find some excitement. Not so different from you and me in some aspects. We all have our battles, some more literal than others.
And what is this board they stand upon? A shield of sorts, similar to yours, but for the dance of the seas?
A surfboard. It's much more than a shield, though. It's the way they connect with the wave, almost like an extension of themselves. Not unlike how I feel with my shield in the heat of battle.
I understand now! It is a noble partnership between warrior and their chosen weapon. And the colors, they are quite pleasing, similar to the bright flashes of lightning when I command the storm.
It takes precision to ride a wave, and courage. One wrong move, and the ocean doesn't forgive. But when it's done right, it's like a perfect mission—you feel that rush of success, like nothing else.
Verily, I can respect that pursuit! Perhaps one day I shall try this... surfing. The closest I have come to such a feeling is flying through the skies astride my trusted hammer, Mjolnir.
I'd pay good money to see that, Thor. But I've got to admit, I like my battles on solid ground. The ocean is unpredictable. Plus, I've had enough of being frozen.
A fair point! The bitter chill of the deep would be unkind to one who has slumbered in ice as you have. For now, let us simply admire the bravery of this surfer from afar.
Take a look at this, Cap. You ever think about trading the shield for a snowboard? You know, for something that doesn't involve saving the world or fighting off bad guys?
Can't say it's crossed my mind, Clint. But I can imagine the thrill. It's just like our battles, in a way – the speed, the balance. It takes skill and guts.
Exactly! And the whole idea of facing forward, down the slope... reminds me of us during a mission – always looking ahead, no matter how steep the drop.
I get your point. It's about focus and adapting to the terrain. Much like working through a fight or strategizing on the move.
And check out that stance – firm, determined. Kind of like yours when you're holding the line. Though, I gotta say, swap the snow for dirt, and that could be you on the battlefield.
I'll take that as a compliment. Though honestly, I'd probably be less graceful on a snowboard. My balance isn't what it used to be after all these years.
Come on, Steve. A super-soldier who's out of balance? I bet you could ride that slope backward and still make it look easy.
Maybe so, but I'll leave the aerial tricks to you, my friend. I'll stick with my shield. It's gotten me through a lot more than snow.
Plus, it doesn't require a lift ticket – I'll give you that. Next Avengers outing, though? I say we hit the slopes. Call it team building.
Let's save the world a few more times first, then I'm in. Just as long as we don't have to wear spandex suits out there.
Spoken like a true traditionalist. Alright, deal. Now, back to the grind?
You lead, I'll follow. Just like on the slope, right?
Right behind you, Cap. Let's get to work.
You know, Steve, the architecture of this room feels strangely reminiscent of a simpler time, don't you think? It's quite ordinary, yet... tranquil in its simplicity.

It does have a sort of timeless quality to it, doesn't it? Reminds me a bit of the '40s, only with modern appliances. I suppose some things don't change all that much—a place for family, a place to share a meal.
Quite so. Even with all the complexities of our lives, the basic human yearnings for comfort and company persist through the ages. It's this very domestic normalcy that we often fight to protect.

That's the truth. We battle gods, monsters, and interdimensional threats, but sometimes it's easy to forget that these small, everyday moments are what it's all about. People just living their lives, safe and sound.
Indeed, Captain. And look at the scattered belongings... tell-tale signs of life being lived. Enchantment and intrigue can be woven from the most mundane of threads, don’t you agree?
You've got a point there, Doctor. Every one of those objects has a story, sort of like us. Someone's favorite mug, a book left on the sofa... small comforts making up a larger tapestry.

Elementary components in a grander cosmic scheme. Still, I can't help but draw parallels to our own lives—our choices are rather like these scattered items, shaping our existence and the fabric of reality.

I think that's something we can both relate to. The choices we've made definitely shaped the world in ways we never could've imagined back in the day. And something tells me our work isn't quite finished yet.
A sage prediction, Steve. Our destinies are as interwoven with the fate of this world as the threads in a carpet. Shall we continue to walk this path, then, side by side, as time and duty demand?
Side by side it is. There's no one I'd rather have watching my six, Strange. For the greater good—and for these quiet moments in someone's kitchen that they'll never know we fought for.
This place, it has a quaint charm to it, doesn't it, Steve? It feels like a scene paused in time, a reality unto its own.
It does at that, Wanda. Peaceful. Reminds me a bit of the past, where things felt simpler. There's a warmth in its colors and the quiet of the street.

I suppose it's the kind of peace I tried to create in Westview. A small part of me still yearns for such simplicity, away from all the turmoil. But I'm learning to find it within, not by changing what's without.
And that's a hard lesson you’ve taken to heart. Holding onto what's important without losing oneself in it. We all seek places of refuge, Wanda. It's what makes us human.
You've been out of time, caught between two worlds – do places like this stir a longing in you? For the era you were born into?

Sometimes, but I’ve learned to carry my time with me, to keep the spirit of it alive in who I am and what I do. This, well, it’s like looking at a picture from an old album. Comforting, but you can’t live in a snapshot.
The solitude here, it's alluring. I still struggle with the noise inside my head, the power... I can't help but wonder, could I truly enjoy such tranquility, or would it always be just out of reach?
Wanda, I think maybe tranquility isn't a place or even a quiet moment. It's being at peace with yourself. With all that power inside you, maybe the real quiet comes from acceptance, not control.
Wise words, Steve. Acceptance is a form of strength too, I suppose. One doesn't always need to be on guard or at the forefront of a battle.
Exactly. We fight when we need to, protect those we care for, but we also need to live, Wanda. We can't lose sight of that, even when the fight seems to be all there is.
You were always the best of us, Captain. Guided by a moral compass that never wavers. Maybe, in another life, I could've found more solace in following that path.

Hey, we've all got our own paths, but remember, it’s never too late to find a new one. You've faced your darkness, and that's something few can say. The future's yours to shape, and something tells me, it's going to be a bright one.

It's funny, looking at this image, I'm reminded of simpler times, back in Sokovia. My mother had plants around our home, nothing as grand as this, but they were hers—a little touch of nature and care amidst all the chaos.

It does have a certain calming effect. Reminds me of home too, back when life was less about fighting off threats and more about the small moments. But Wanda, is there something about this image that's troubling you?

No, nothing troubling. It's just... sometimes these small pieces of the past, they bring back memories, and not all of them are good. But it's important, isn't it? To remember where we came from, the people we loved.
I believe it is. It grounds us, gives our fight meaning. After all, we're not just fighting against something; we're fighting for something—for those memories, those people.

True, Steve. And there's a certain strength in acknowledging our past, shaping a better future without being beholden to what was. That plant in the green vase—it stands out, doesn't it? A vibrant life against the stillness of the room.
It stands resilient—much like you, Wanda. Despite everything, you find a way to flourish. We both know loss, and somehow, we've managed to keep moving forward.
I guess you can say, we can do this all day, can't we?
Yeah, I suppose we can. Though I don't mind the idea of doing something as peaceful as tending to a plant like that instead.
Maybe in another life, Steve. For now, we keep fighting the good fight.
Always. Just remember, you've got a team that's got your back, Wanda. No matter the odds.
Thank you, Steve. It means a lot, coming from you—America's original super soldier.
And thank you, Wanda, for always striving to be more than what your past dictates. Now, let's focus on the mission ahead, but maybe later, we can find a little more time for moments like these.
Seems like an enthralling demonstration of human daring, doesn't it, Steve? The sheer velocity, the balance—there's something almost mystical about it.
They sure are pushing the limits, Stephen. Reminds me of the kind of fearlessness we see on the field. Racing not just against each other, but against the edge of what's possible.
Indeed. The physics are elementary, but watching it sparks a curiosity in me about the boundaries of human potential. They're like the ancient charioteers, risking it all for the thrill of victory.
It's the kind of courage and commitment that can be inspiring. Although, sometimes I think about the costs, too. It’s not just about speed or winning—it's about discipline and self-control.

Very astute, and very much in your character to consider the integrity of the act, not just the spectacle. As for me, I can't help but admire the precise control they must exert over these mechanical beasts. It's not unlike channeling the mystic arts, a fine balance between force and finesse.
You've got a point there. Both take years of practice, determination, and a lot of focus—something you and I know a thing or two about. They're in their own way, warriors of the track.

Warriors indeed. But rather than fight darkness, they chase light—the glittering light of triumph. Yet we all strive toward our own goals, be they on a battlefield, in the depths of space-time, or on a racetrack.
True, and whether we're holding a shield, casting spells, or gripping handlebars, it’s that pursuit that defines us. It's that human spirit to keep pushing forward, no matter what.
Well said, Captain. And speaking of handlebars, I do believe I've read about you commandeering a motorcycle with quite some flair in your day.

Had to make do with what I had during the war. Motorcycles don't fly or open portals, but they do get you where you need to go—fast. Always respected those who can handle them on a professional level.
As have I. Perhaps when the world is not on the brink of another calamity, we might consider a less perilous, two-wheeled excursion. For leisure, rather than escape or pursuit.
I'd like that. Might be nice to enjoy the ride without something at stake. Just let me know if you plan on bending any laws of physics on the way, Doctor.
You'll be the first to know, Captain. Assuring you, of course, that any manipulation of reality would be solely for the enhancement of our journey, nothing more.
I'll hold you to that, Strange. For now, let's enjoy the simplicity of this race. It's not magic, but it's still pretty impressive.
Look at that, a simple creature enjoying the simplicity of existence. You know, in some parallel universe, that dog could be a cosmic entity, guarding realms we can't even fathom.

That's quite a thought, but I think there's something to be said for the simple things, even in our world. This dog might not be guarding realms, but I bet it's loyal and that in its own way, it's a hero to someone.
Indeed, loyalty is a universal currency, Cap. Speaking of which, in all your time – past and present – have you ever had a chance to enjoy such a companion?

Once or twice I thought about it, but duty always seemed to get in the way. Seems like every time I settle in, the world has another crisis. Still, I can see why people value pets. Companions that don't ask for much, but give a lot back.

They do present an uncomplicated form of support, unlike the complexities we face daily. A respite from the chaos. Do you think you might indulge in a canine companion now that you've passed the shield?

Maybe, Stephen. Though I passed the shield, the sense of duty doesn't just vanish. But, you’re right, maybe it's time for some simplicity. Who knows, maybe there's a lucky dog in another universe just waiting to teach me a thing or two about taking it easy.
I'll be sure to keep an eye out across the multiverse. But for now, maybe just a stroll through the park, Steve. One universe at a time, eh?

One universe at a time, Doctor. And a stroll sounds good. Let's enjoy the moment while it’s quiet. No dark dimensions or infinity stones to worry about, just the fresh air and the sound of leaves underfoot.
Agreed. Lead the way, Captain. The Cloak can rest too. After all, not every day we get to walk the dog, even if it's just in theory.
And I think we can both appreciate the value of a good walk. It's the little things, Strange. Always the little things that keep us grounded.

Steve, I find this image quite stirring. It appears to depict a small human child engaging in what I believe is called "skiing" under the supervision of an adult. As I understand, this activity necessitates a considerable amount of trust and tutelage. Would you agree that this is illustrative of the human necessity for guidance in mastering new skills?

Yeah, Vision, you've hit the nail on the head. Skiing can be tough to pick up, especially for kids. It's about more than just trust though—it's about passing on skills and courage. That's one way we humans help the next generation be a little braver and better than we were.

Indeed, the concept of courage is particularly fascinating. The child would need to overcome the natural fear of rapid downhill movement. The adult's presence likely provides a psychological safety net, akin to my role when I joined you and the team, despite my initial uncertainty about my place among the Avengers.

That's true. Just like the adult is there to catch the kid if they fall, we were there for you—and you for us. It's not just about physical safety, but also about encouraging each other to be our best. You certainly have become an indispensable part of the team, Vision.

Your words are heartening, Captain. To extend the metaphor further, do you see yourself in a role akin to the guiding adult in this picture, shepherding those around you through challenges and triumphs?

I suppose you could see it that way. I try to be there for folks, to guide them through tough spots. But it's a team effort. We all have our strengths, and we've all taken turns leading or supporting when the situation calls for it. I've learned a lot from you all too, Vision.

The interdependence you describe is indeed a hallmark of effective teamwork. I ponder whether the child will one day recount this experience as a pivotal moment in their development, much like we reflect on our past battles and how they've shaped us.

They might, Vision. Sometimes it's these small moments that stick with us—the first time we try something new, the people who were there, the fears we faced. They're part of what makes us who we are. It's not just about the big fights or world-saving. It's about growing up and helping others do the same.
